title: How do I deal with these kinds of people?
body:
Just finished a game, I was nice to someone in need who was somewhat on the brink of AFKing due to umm, 'being sad cuz he knows he can't play a certain champion', and the bot lane just automatically (and in a very salty way) assumed that I was premade with the guy I was nice to...

How do I deal with people like this??
I mean we lost due to all four of my teammates surrendering for some reason when we did have a very good chance but eh, either way I got S- and a HexTech so I'm not too worried about it

replies.body:
Easy! Just mute them. I mean I really do way better when start of the game I just mute everyone. Reason why I mute everyone is because I will do what I want to do and you will learn from it. 

For example:

I'm feeding really hard and I know that I am feeding but when your team mates start flaming you about how you're feeding and you're so shit, you do not need these type of remarks, you already know you are feeding and you will likely end up getting mad and start flaming them back. Also, I know some team mates are good and try to tell you what to do but eventually you will learn by yourself and chances of you playing with the same people is less than 50%. So I say mute all of them and just concentrate on playing the game. I have a mind set of I'm playing this game not to make friends but to win so therefore when I play I mute everyone and not chat. You would be avoiding so many situations like the one you just described. If you muted them all then do you think that you would be here writing about this?

No I wouldn't, but I don't like to mute anyone cuz communication is still key, and maybe there's hope in people (or I'm just far too optimistic) but I don't like to mute people purely because I still need to see what they say incase it does benefit the game like a chat MIA instead of a ping etc

As a general rule, once people start commenting on your mothers whereabouts the previous night, they won't have anything constructive to say the rest of the game. Unfortunately once people start flaming that much, they don't generally stop. You can safely mute these kind of people.

Oh yes there's a battle in this post between Ttomes and Qapla, lemme spectate xD

I did notice Qapla's been quite salty going off on random tangents in a few posts now..
Plus Ttomes uses the Jinx wink, ;) ;) ;)

I had an ARAM today, where 23 mins into the game, I said in /all chat "GP 4 assists, real team player" as he hadn't even dropped his ult on a teamfight once. Everyone else was around 20+ assists.
Not exactly the most offensive or toxic thing I could have said, but the guy got so mad about it. "I'm fucking sick of you %%%%s blah blah blah", "fucking think your tough from behind your keyboard blah blah blah" etc. Guy retreats to fountain (afk but still typing) and continues to rant at me. He was far more offensive or toxic than my comment that set him off.
I say "It was a pretty benign comment, I think you're overreacting" and "I think you need to harden up or get off the internet". My team basically just told the guy to grow up.
Eventually he rejoined the game.

It's people like this that make me question all these threads I read about toxic players, at least half of them are just too thin skinned to be interacting with others on the internet.

[edit] Team games aren't for everyone, there are plenty of solo games available for you softies.

Unfortunately, there was nothing benign about your comment. It was clearly very passive-aggressive (something Riot Lyte has recently said is 'not acceptable' and considered now to be Unsportsmanlike Behaviour *and* report-worthy) and it was what you *didn't* say, but were clearly implying, that set this guy off. Who knows, maybe you were just the last in a long line of people casting shade on that player for poor performance which is why he unleashed on you? No, he wasn't participating to the same extent of the rest of your team, but if you are going to say something negative to them about that, then you should expect their response to be not so positive.

As for team games not being suited for 'softies', that's just entitled bullshit on your part. Every player is a real person. You don't know them, you don't know their story. To expect everyone else to be as edgy and 'hard' as you clearly are simply because they play a multi player online game is just fkn arrogant on your part. 

And, before you unleash on me, I can be just as passive-aggressive ingame and am sometimes downright nasty because I have a low tolerance for ineptitude and stupidity and I arrogantly expect everyone else to be of the same performance/skill level, or above, as myself and get annoyed when they make, what I consider to be, basic blunders and stupid mistakes or they act like princesses who the rules don't apply to or little entitled twats that the world revolves around.

But I am fully aware of my tendencies and reign that crap in and monitor what I say. I am 100% responsible for how I react to other people. It's not their fault what I do or say regardless. I can *think* it all I want, but I do my best now to keep it in my mouth.

One of the funniest/nastiest convos I remember having with another player (this was back on NA before OCE existed) I still find funny even though it now makes me cringe at the same time. It was hilarious, but completely evil, and when I think about it now I feel bad even though it still makes me giggle (because I'm an asshole like that). The guy/gal I burnt so thoroughly I knew, and still know, nothing about. For all I know, my exchange with them could have had a profound and long lasting negative effect on them. Or maybe not. That's the thing. We *don't know*, either the people we play with or anything about them or how our actions and words may affect them. 

TL;DR: Tread lightly, and don't be That Guy.

Lmao.
So implications (which are very subjective), and "what I didn't say" are just cause for a player behaving like this?
You are so funny.

And to be crystal clear, I never abuse anyone, even if they're feeding, unless they start the shit talk first. I will offer advice, such as "hey, the whole enemy team is AD and you are feeding, try building some armour". etc.
When you see players that don't engage in teamfights, only wait to clean up after (maybe it's acceptable with champs like Yi, but not Gangplank, who was the subject of discussion) in ARAM, have very low assists, but still more deaths than kills, yeah... this dude deserves a comment or two. Not spiteful comments, just a "how about teamplay rather than personal gain play?".

I say this because I prize myself on being a team player. Like, earlier today I had a game (ARAM), where I was Singed, on a team with 4 ADC's.
Our Kog'maw chose to go AD rather than AP despite the team selection, and ranted and raved at me "feeding". Calling me "retard" and such. I built tank, we lost the game, and low and behold, in postgame stats, who had the most damage dealt to champs (out of both teams) ? Tank Singed did. The last time I played Singed before this game, I got an S grade.

Who is the fool that doesn't know how to play? The tank that out-damages all the ADC's, or the Kog that thinks K/D/A means everything? (and I of course had most assists).

"GP 4 assists, real team player" and "how about teamplay rather than personal gain play?" are poles apart in sentiment and intent. Seeing as you stated you said/have said both of these, surely you yourself can tell the almost positive statement from the snidely negative one and which one is more likely to illicit the type of responsive actions/words you are hoping for?

> So implications (which are very subjective), and "what I didn't say" are just cause for a player behaving like this?

Short answer? Yes.
Longer answer? Yes, if they are the type to have little emotional control and flare up easily over direct or, in this case, indirect slights cast at them or are simply is a 'bad place' in that moment.

> You are so funny.

I like to think I have my moments...
{{sticker:slayer-jinx-wink}}

Unfortunately some people are quite easily tilted no matter how benign your intentions were. The best 'counter' is to refrain from referring to any players directly in your comments. If you need to correct someone's gameplay, type "we should" rather than "you should", for example, your team has no map pressure due to lack of vision, rather than "Sona, why don't you have any wards?", you could say "We need to ward".

If you're unfortunate enough to get someone that is already flaming, or start flaming due to things out of your control, the best way to 'defuse' them is to take the don't feed the troll approach and not reply to toxic comments.

Just ignore them. This isn't even that big of an issue. Who cares what randoms on the internet think? Mute them and get on with your game. They weren't flaming you or anything so I'm sure it wasn't that big of a deal. But good on you for trying to be nice.
